user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_TaskFindIdBySystemData:
```c
int32 OS_TaskFindIdBySystemData(osal_id_t *task_id, const void *sysdata, size_t sysdata_size)
{
    int32             return_code;
    OS_object_token_t token;

    /* Check parameters */
    OS_CHECK_POINTER(task_id);

    /* The "sysdata" and "sysdata_size" must be passed to the underlying impl for validation */
    return_code = OS_TaskValidateSystemData_Impl(sysdata, sysdata_size);
    if (return_code != OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        return return_code;
    }

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdGetBySearch(OS_LOCK_MODE_GLOBAL, LOCAL_OBJID_TYPE, OS_TaskIdMatchSystemData_Impl,
                                         (void *)sysdata, &token);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        *task_id = OS_ObjectIdFromToken(&token);

        OS_ObjectIdRelease(&token);
    }

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_TaskFindIdBySystemData:
#define OS_CHECK_POINTER(ptr) BUGCHECK((ptr)!=NULL,OS_INVALID_POINTER)
...
int32 OS_TaskValidateSystemData_Impl(const void *sysdata, size_t sysdata_size)
{
    if (sysdata == NULL || sysdata_size != sizeof(pthread_t))
    {
        return OS_INVALID_POINTER;
    }
    return OS_SUCCESS;
}
...
int32 OS_ObjectIdGetBySearch(OS_lock_mode_t lock_mode, osal_objtype_t idtype, OS_ObjectMatchFunc_t MatchFunc, void *arg,
                             OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    int32 return_code;

    OS_ObjectIdTransactionInit(lock_mode, idtype, token);

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdFindNextMatch(MatchFunc, arg, token);

    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        /*
         * The "ConvertToken" routine will return with the global lock
         * in a state appropriate for returning to the caller, as indicated
         * by the "lock_mode" parameter.
         */
        return_code = OS_ObjectIdConvertToken(token);
    }
    else
    {
        OS_ObjectIdTransactionCancel(token);
    }

    return return_code;
}
...
bool OS_TaskIdMatchSystemData_Impl(void *ref, const OS_object_token_t *token, const OS_common_record_t *obj)
{
    const pthread_t *               target = (const pthread_t *)ref;
    OS_impl_task_internal_record_t *impl;

    impl = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_impl_task_table, *token);

    return (pthread_equal(*target, impl->id) != 0);
}
...
typedef uint32 osal_id_t
...
typedef int32_t   int32
...
typedef struct OS_object_token OS_object_token_t
...
static inline osal_id_t OS_ObjectIdFromToken(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    return token->obj_id;
}
...
void OS_ObjectIdRelease(OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    OS_ObjectIdTransactionFinish(token, NULL);
}
...
#define OS_SUCCESS (0)
...
int32 OS_ObjectIdFindNextMatch(OS_ObjectMatchFunc_t MatchFunc, void *arg, OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    int32               return_code;
    uint32              obj_count;
    OS_common_record_t *base;
    OS_common_record_t *record;

    return_code   = OS_ERR_NAME_NOT_FOUND;
    base          = &OS_common_table[OS_GetBaseForObjectType(token->obj_type)];
    obj_count     = OS_GetMaxForObjectType(token->obj_type);
    token->obj_id = OS_OBJECT_ID_UNDEFINED;

    while (true)
    {
        ++token->obj_idx;

        if (token->obj_idx >= obj_count)
        {
            break;
        }

        record = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(base, *token);

        if (OS_ObjectIdDefined(record->active_id) && MatchFunc(arg, token, record))
        {
            return_code   = OS_SUCCESS;
            token->obj_id = record->active_id;
            break;
        }
    }

    return return_code;
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
No usage of any <string.h> functions (memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, strspn, etc.) is present in the provided code fragments, so there are no direct candidates that could violate MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17. Specific justifications:

- OS_TaskValidateSystemData_Impl explicitly validates the sysdata pointer and its size (sysdata != NULL and sysdata_size == sizeof(pthread_t)), preventing out-of-bounds access when the pointer is later treated as a pointer to pthread_t.
- OS_TaskFindIdBySystemData passes the validated sysdata pointer through OS_ObjectIdGetBySearch without performing any string operations itself.
- OS_TaskIdMatchSystemData_Impl casts the arg to const pthread_t * and uses pthread_equal(*target, impl->id); this dereferences a pthread_t only after validation, and does not use any string.h routines.
- OS_ObjectIdFindNextMatch and OS_ObjectIdGetBySearch iterate/search object tables and invoke the provided MatchFunc; the shown code does not call any string.h functions or perform byte/string copying operations.

If there are other modules or implementations not shown here (e.g., implementations of OS_ObjectIdConvertToken, OS_ObjectIdTransactionInit/Finish, OS_ObjectIdRelease, or other hidden match functions), those would need to be inspected for use of <string.h> functions. Based solely on the provided code, there are no suspicious fragments to investigate for Rule 21.17.
